title: Alterations in the Spectrum of Spontaneous Rifampicin-Resistance Mutations in the Bacillus subtilis rpoB Gene after Cultivation in the Human Spaceflight Environment
background: Spaceflight presents unique physical stressors including cosmic radiation, microgravity, vibration, electromagnetic fields, and altered atmospheric compositions that may affect microbial mutagenesis and evolution.
objective: To investigate the effect of Bacillus subtilis exposure to the human spaceflight environment on growth, mutagenic frequency, and spectrum of mutations to rifampicin resistance (RifR) in the rpoB gene.
methods: B. subtilis cells were cultivated in Biological Research in Canister-Petri Dish Fixation Units (BRIC-PDFUs) on two separate ISS missions (BRIC-18 and BRIC-21) with matching asynchronous ground controls. RifR mutants were isolated and rpoB gene regions sequenced to determine mutation spectra.
results: No significant differences in growth or RifR mutation frequency were found between flight and ground samples. However, dramatic differences in mutation spectra were observed, including two novel rpoB alleles (Q137R and L489S) exclusively in flight samples.
conclusion: Exposure to the human spaceflight environment causes unique stresses on bacteria, leading to alterations in their mutagenic potential and potentially affecting microbial evolution in space habitats.

learning_notes.note: The study conducted two separate ISS missions (BRIC-18 and BRIC-21) using Bacillus subtilis spores cultivated in BRIC-PDFU hardware, with 122-hour and 25-hour incubation periods respectively. This dual-mission approach provided robust validation of spaceflight effects on microbial mutagenesis.

While no significant differences were found in growth (average 3.98×10⁶ CFU flight vs 1.10×10⁷ ground in BRIC-18) or RifR mutation frequency (6.9×10⁻⁶ flight vs 7.54×10⁻⁶ ground), dramatic alterations in mutation spectra occurred, demonstrating that spaceflight stresses specifically affect mutation types rather than rates.

Two never-before-observed rpoB mutations (Q137R and L489S) were identified exclusively in flight samples, with L489S comprising 32 out of 72 mutants in BRIC-21 flight samples. These spaceflight-specific mutations suggest unique molecular mechanisms of stress-induced mutagenesis in the space environment.

The research used rigorous asynchronous ground controls maintained in ISS Environmental Simulation Chambers following exact flight temperature profiles (22.8±0.07°C flight vs 22.8±0.21°C ground in BRIC-21), ensuring that observed differences were due to spaceflight factors rather than experimental conditions.

Mutations in rpoB can have far-reaching consequences beyond antibiotic resistance, including alterations in global gene regulation, activation of cryptic metabolic capabilities, and changes in susceptibility to other antibiotics, making these findings critical for understanding microbial evolution in space habitats.

The study was supported by NASA grants NNX12AN70G and NNX14AT38G and utilized SpaceX Cargo Resupply missions (SpaceX-3 and SpaceX-6) for sample transport, demonstrating NASA's ongoing commitment to understanding microbial behavior in spaceflight environments.

Analysis of transition vs transversion mutations revealed that A:G and C:T transitions predominated in both flight and ground samples, but flight samples exhibited unique T:A transversions not found in ground controls, indicating spaceflight-specific effects on DNA damage and repair mechanisms.
